item.title: Israel-Hamas War: First Aid Trucks Move Through Crossing to Gaza
item.description: The United Nations said the 20-truck convoy carried “life-saving supplies,” which the World Health Organization warned would “barely begin to address the escalating health needs” in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: South Korea’s Crowd Crush Disaster Prompts No Changes at the Top
item.description: Families of the 159 people crushed to death last year say the government has never acknowledged its mistakes or accepted responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A temporary memorial to the Itaewon victims set up this month in front of City Hall in Seoul.

item.title: Ukraine, a Sniper Mission and the Myth of the ‘Good Kill’
item.description: A New York Times reporter who is a former Marine has a conversation with a Ukrainian sniper about morality in war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian snipers overlooking a Russian position in southern Ukraine.

item.title: Fear Grows in Israel for Sick or Wounded Hostages
item.description: Hamas released two American hostages on Friday, but concern is rising about the hundreds still held in Gaza, especially the injured and ill.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier taping a photograph of her friend Ron Sherman to a wall near the Israeli Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv.

item.title: New Evidence Found of Rape and Torture by Russian Forces in Ukraine
item.description: A U.N. report documented cases in the southern regions of Kherson and Zaporizhzhia, which remain partly under Moscow’s control.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cell at a prison in Kherson, Ukraine, where Russian forces held and tortured captives.

item.title: Nawaz Sharif Returning to Pakistan and Hoping for a Political Comeback
item.description: After nearly four years in exile, Mr. Sharif, a three-time prime minister, will hold a big gathering before an upcoming election.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, in London in 2022. He left Pakistan in 2019 in for health reasons after being granted bail from a seven-year prison sentence.

item.title: A Small Country Far From Ukraine Is Sending Hundreds toWar, on Both Sides
item.description: Scores of young Nepali men have gone to fight, some lured by Russia’s promise of work, others to fight for Ukraine, raising the prospect of Nepalis fighting one another in a distant war.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Uma Bista for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shanta Thapaliya holding a photograph of her brother Sandip, who joined the Russian Army after struggling to find a long-term job in Nepal.

item.title: Venezuela-U.S. Relations Soften Ahead of Key Primary Election
item.description: The release of political prisoners and the lifting of some U.S. sanctions comes as Venezuela’s opposition prepares to elect a candidate to challenge the country’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky, Isayen Herrera and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, an opposition presidential candidate, holding a rally last month in Maturin, Venezuela.

item.title: Passion for Palestinian Cause Had Faded, but Violence in Gaza Reignited It
item.description: The Israeli bombardment of Gaza, in retaliation for a deadly Hamas attack on southern Israel, brought a new outpouring of support in the Arab world for the Palestinian quest for a state.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Moroccans waved Palestinian flags and shouted slogans in the capital, Rabat, on Wednesday to show solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: Junta Says Niger’s Ousted President Tried to Escape. His Lawyer Says, No Way.
item.description: Mohamed Bazoum, who was toppled in a coup, has been under house arrest with his family for nearly three months while leaders in Africa, the United States and Europe have pushed for his release.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: President Mohamed Bazoum’s fate and whereabouts remained uncertain on Friday.

item.title: David Suzuki Warned Canada About Mistreating Nature, but Says, ‘We’ve Failed’
item.description: After cautioning about environmental damage on TV for decades, David Suzuki, 87, one of Canada’s most famous scientists, felt a sense of defeat as he watched forests burn and temperatures soar this summer.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Melissa Renwick for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Suzuki, the science broadcaster, prolific author and perhaps Canada’s most prominent environmentalist, on Quadra Island, in British Columbia.

item.title: Dutch Royals Confront South Africa’s Colonial Legacy
item.description: The king has previously apologized for his family’s role in slavery, but some South Africans seek a direct apology and reparations from the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Willem Alexander and Queen Maxima of the Netherlands visited the Slave Lodge in Cape Town, South Africa, on Friday. Indigenous groups are seeking an apology for atrocities committed during 150 years of colonialism.

item.title: Giorgia Meloni Says She’s Breaking Up With Andrea Giambruno
item.description: On social media, the prime minister said her 10-year relationship with a news anchor “ends here,” after a hot mic and video footage picked him up apparently hitting on other women.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy arriving for opening night at the opera in Milan with Andrea Giambruno in December.

item.title: Another Setback for Rishi Sunak As Labour Snatch Two Seats
item.description: Britain’s main opposition party overturned large majorities in two parliamentary elections, in a stinging blow to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Britain’s Labour Party leader, Keir Starmer, celebrates with newly elected candidate Alistair Strathern. With two new electoral wins, Mr. Starmer said, Labour is redrawing the political map.

item.title: Peter Nygard Lured Women to His Office’s Bedroom, Witnesses Testified
item.description: Five women accusing Peter Nygard of sexual assault completed their testimonies this week as prosecutors prepare to close their case in Toronto.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: Russians Who Moved to Israel to Escape Ukraine War Are in the Middle of Another One
item.description: Thousands of citizens with Jewish heritage left for Israel after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: People gathering at a solidarity service for Israeli victims of the Hamas attacks at the Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center in Moscow last week.

item.title: How $17.2 Million in Gold and Cash Disappeared From Toronto’s Airport
item.description: A lawsuit offers a glimpse into the victim’s view of the April heist, though the case remains unsolved.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chris Young/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The theft at Pearson Airport in Toronto occurred in April.

item.title: In Global Conflict Zones, Hospitals and Doctors Are No Longer Spared
item.description: Over the last two decades, medical facilities and staff have become casualties of war more frequently, in violation of international law.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Hundreds were feared dead after an explosion at a hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday as Israel and Hamas continued their conflict.

item.title: Chapter 1: To Take Control, She Had to Run
item.description: This is the first part of a series by The Interpreter that examines how, for two young women, chasing opportunity in India has been a fight for their lives.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub, Emily Schmall, Shalini Venugopal Bhagat and Andrea Bruce
item.media:description: Nasreen Parveen, 20.

item.title: Biden and Aides Advise Israel to Avoid Striking Hezbollah
item.description: U.S. officials learned that the Israeli defense minister and other military officials supported a pre-emptive strike on Hezbollah. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been cautious.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Ronen Bergman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Biden met with Prime Minister Netanyahu of Israel and his war cabinet on Wednesday. The two governments have tried to present a strong united front in public in the wake of the attacks by Hamas.

item.title: Promised Aid to Gaza Is Stalled by Wrangling, as Conditions Worsen
item.description: Israel, Egypt, the United Nations and others are still working out the details of delivering food, water and medicine, as Israel prepares a possible ground invasion.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tents for displaced Palestinians in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip, on Friday.

item.title: Since Israel-Hamas War, Events About Palestinian Culture Have Been Canceled
item.description: Some fear that the raft of cancellations at this moment of war and tragedy is limiting opportunities to foster dialogue and greater understanding.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:description: An award ceremony honoring the Palestinian author Adania Shibli was canceled at the Frankfurt Book Fair, one of several events touching on Palestinian culture and society called off since the war.

item.title: Hamas Releases 2 U.S. Hostages, a Mother and Daughter
item.description: Judith Raanan and her daughter, Natalie Raanan, were kidnapped from a kibbutz near the Gaza border during the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Judith Raanan and her daughter, Natalie, were released by Hamas on Friday.

item.title: Man in Poland Posed as Mannequin to Steal Jewelry
item.description: A 22-year-old man in Warsaw posed motionless, carrying a shopping bag, beside mannequins in a storefront window, the police said. Security officials caught him.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A photo, which the police distributed with the suspect’s face hidden to protect his identity, shows a man in a Warsaw clothing store pretending to be a mannequin.

item.title: Israeli Airstrike Hits Greek Orthodox Church Compound in Gaza City
item.description: Israel’s military acknowledged it had damaged the church site while targeting what it said was a Hamas command center nearby.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Ameera Harouda

item.title: When Saying Nothing Is Saying Something
item.description: Leagues and teams probably would have preferred not to take a public position on the Israel-Hamas war. That they could not avoid doing so is their own fault.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Food and Water Are Unlikely to Flow Into Gaza on Friday, Officials Say
item.description: Egypt, Israel, the United States and the United Nations were still negotiating over thorny issues, including who would inspect the shipments for weapons, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Trucks carrying humanitarian aid for the Gaza Strip parked outside Rafah border gate in Egypt on Friday.

item.title: Storm Babet Drops ‘Exceptional’ Amount of Rain on Scotland
item.description: Storm Babet has already dumped more than 26 inches of rain on the region, far more than is normal for this time of year.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Huge waves from the storm crashing against the harbor wall in Stonehaven, south of Aberdeen, Scotland, on Friday.

item.title: With Raids Across Dnipro, Ukraine May Be Seeking New Front
item.description: Military experts are reporting extensive strikes on Russian-held territory in the south, potentially with the goal of establishing a bridgehead on the east bank of the Dnipro.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian defensive fortification on a lake on the Dnipro River in the Kherson region.

item.title: 1948: Lateness of Yugoslav Trains is Laid to a Negative Attitude
item.description: The country’s Communist government blamed crews for the increasing number of costly railroad delays.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: 13 Palestinians and an Israeli Officer Killed as Violence Surges in West Bank
item.description: The deadliest fighting occurred in the Nur Shams refugee camp, where Israeli forces also carried out a rare drone strike.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Rami Nazzal and Adam Sella
item.media:description: Israeli security forces during clashes with Palestinian demonstrators in the occupied West Bank city of Ramallah on Friday.

item.title: Javier Milei, a ‘Mini-Trump,’ Could Be Argentina’s Next President
item.description: The global far-right movement faces an important test in Argentina’s election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Javier Milei is the favorite to win the presidential election in Argentina outright on Sunday or head to a runoff next month.

item.title: The Most Australian Story to Ever Come Out of Vietnam
item.description: Hotels hold secrets, and some of them are a little stranger than others.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Metropole hotel in Hanoi, Vietnam.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: An address by President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden spoke from inside the Oval Office.

item.title: Key Suspect in Assassination of Haiti’s President Is Arrested
item.description: Joseph Félix Badio, a former government official, has been wanted for years in connection with the 2021 killing of President Jovenel Moïse.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:description: Police officers in Pétion-Ville, Haiti, walking past a mural of President Jovenel Moïse, who was killed in 2021.

item.title: Canada Pulls 41 Diplomats as India Threatens to Revoke Their Immunity
item.description: The diplomats and 42 family members left amid growing tension over Canada’s assertion that India was complicit in the killing of a Sikh leader in British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Mélanie Joly, Canada’s foreign minister, right, sitting next to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, said that India’s plan to revoke diplomatic immunity was “unreasonable and escalatory.”

item.title: Israelis Can Travel to U.S. Without a Visa Under New Biden Program
item.description: The change should make it easier and faster for Israelis seeking to flee the war.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at Ben-Gurion International Airport near Lod, Israel, last week.

item.title: Mexico’s Top Human Rights Official Resigns, Handing Off Unsolved Mass Disappearance Case
item.description: Alejandro Encinas spent years investigating the high-profile case of 43 missing students, but said he was stepping down to work on a presidential election campaign.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Alejandro Encinas, a longtime friend and political ally of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, has been at odds with the Mexican armed forces.

item.title: U.S. Shoots Down Several Missiles and Drones Launched From Yemen
item.description: A flurry of incidents underscored the heightened risks that the conflict between Israel and Hamas could spiral into a wider war.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ryan U. Kledzik/U.S. Naval Forces Europe-Africa, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by the U.S. Navy shows a Navy destroyer. A U.S. warship shot down three cruise missiles and several drones.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Gaza Aid Deal Sees Progress
item.description: Plus South Korea’s protest culture.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Humanitarian aid provided by the United Nations is loaded onto a United Arab Emirates Air Force C-130H-30 Hercules turboprop military transport aircraft at Dubai International Airport before departure for Cairo on Thursday.

item.title: Gaza Hospital Blast Death Toll Between 100-300, U.S. Officials Estimate
item.description: American officials say the blast on Tuesday likely killed 100 to 300 people. Gaza officials estimate the death toll closer to 500.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The scene outside the Al Ahli Hospital in Gaza, a day after a deadly explosion on Tuesday.

item.title: What the Laws of War Say About Forced Displacement and ‘Human Shields’
item.description: Amid the sorrow and anger over the ongoing violence, the core principles of humanitarian law are simple. Civilians must be protected.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians leaving the northern Gaza Strip, on their way south, near Khan Younis on Friday, Oct. 13.

item.title: Hurricane Norma Churns Toward Baja California Peninsula
item.description: The storm was forecast to unleash heavy rain and could cause flooding and mudslides in southern Baja California Sur this weekend, forecasters said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Hurricane Norma’s winds had reached 115 miles per hour as it approached the southern parts of Cabo San Lucas and the western coast of Mexico.

item.title: Deal Lays Groundwork for Aid to Reach Desperate Gazans, Officials Say
item.description: Trucks loaded with food and medicine are lined up tantalizingly close to people who need it, separated only by border gates that war and diplomatic wrangling have kept closed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg, Emma Bubola, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Vivian Yee and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: People looking through the rubble of a home in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, that was destroyed by an airstrike on Thursday.

item.title: Van Gogh Museum Pulls Pokémon Cards After Frenzy
item.description: The museum in Amsterdam stopped giving out Pikachu cards that were part of a special collaboration after extreme demand.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Remko de Waal/ANP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam gave out special Pokémon cards to celebrate the museum’s 50th anniversary and recognize the link between the Dutch artist and Japan. Then things got nutty.

item.title: Photos: Life Under the Bombs in Khan Younis, Gaza
item.description: Civilians in Gaza face an unending nightmare of airstrikes and deprivation — if they manage to survive.
item.dc:creator: Samar Abu Elouf, Yousef Masoud and Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Medical workers with a boy, who was injured in a strike, at a hospital in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israelis Praise Biden Visit but Fear U.S. Constraints on Action
item.description: President Biden promised undying American backing for Israel in its war against Hamas. But that won’t mean U.S. support for everything Israel does.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Biden with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Tel Aviv on Wednesday.

item.title: China’s Military is Making Risky Moves and Adding Nuclear Warheads, U.S. Says
item.description: The Defense Department said in a report to Congress that Beijing’s “coercive” air intercepts were aimed at intimidating U.S. forces in the region.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: China has been stepping up military pressure on Taiwan, sending jets, drones, bombers and other planes near the island.

item.title: Chasing Jack the Ripper Through the Streets of Modern London
item.description: Tours devoted to the Victorian-era serial killer are thriving, even if the area they explore looks decidedly modern.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: The Five: The Untold Lives of the Women Killed by Jack the Ripper (Book)
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mick Priestly has been giving Jack the Ripper tours through Whitechapel for a decade.

item.title: What Is Hezbollah, the Group Posing a Threat to Israel from the North?
item.description: For decades, Hezbollah has been a significant force in Lebanon, wielding both political power and military strength — all while engaging in tit-for-tat skirmishes with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters carrying out training exercises during a news media visit to one of their camps in the village of Aaramta, in southern Lebanon, in May.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Visits Israel in a Display of Support From U.K.
item.description: The British prime minister met his Israeli counterpart, Benjamin Netanyahu, during the trip, which follows a visit by President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain arriving at Ben Gurion Airport, near Tel Aviv, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Republicans Use Israel Attack to Stoke Fears About U.S.-Mexico Border
item.description: G.O.P. lawmakers and candidates regularly invoke record-high border crossings to address a range of issues, including crime and jobs.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nikki Haley and other members of the Republican Party in trying to tie the Hamas attack to the United States’ southern border through sweeping and largely unsubstantiated claims.

item.title: Russia Detains a U.S. Journalist, Alsu Kurmasheva
item.description: Alsu Kurmasheva, who holds dual U.S.-Russian citizenship and works in Prague, was charged with failing to register as a foreign agent after going to Russia for family reasons.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The newsroom of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty broadcaster in Moscow.

item.title: What South Korea’s Frequent Protests Say About Its Politics
item.description: Part rock concert, part revival meeting, the rallies reveal a country increasingly polarized over its leader, Yoon Suk Yeol.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: President Biden’s wartime visit to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden’s visit to Israel, including a meeting with Benjamin Netanyahu, has been complicated by a deadly hospital blast and rising tensions in the region.

item.title: Javier Milei and His 5 Cloned Dogs in Argentina’s Election
item.description: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian, might soon be Argentina’s next president. He credits his cloned “four-legged children.”
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Javier Milei at home in 2018 with his cloned mastiff puppies.

item.title: Families of Hamas Hostages Split on Invasion of Gaza
item.description: The families are torn between wanting their loved ones returned safely at any cost and concern about more loss of life.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Photographs of Israelis believed to have been kidnapped by Hamas on Oct. 7 on display this week near the Israel Defense Forces’ headquarters in Tel Aviv.

item.title: First Venezuelan Migrants Deported Under New U.S. Policy Arrive
item.description: The deportation of migrants who had entered the U.S. illegally came as the Biden administration lifted some sanctions against Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Frances Robles
item.category: Chatham House (The Royal Institute of International Affairs)
item.media:credit: Veronica G. Cardenas/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants boarding a plane in Harlingen, Texas, on Wednesday for deportation to Venezuela.

item.title: 300 Arrested on Capitol Hill in Call for Cease-Fire in Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Rallies over the Israel-Hamas war have continued to be held across the country and in world capitals.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters asked for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war, inside the Cannon House Office Building on Wednesday.

item.title: Jacob Lew, Biden Nominee for Ambassador to Israel, Is Grilled by Senators
item.description: Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused Jacob Lew of having enabled the rise of Iran-backed terror groups as President Obama’s Treasury secretary.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob J. Lew, President Biden’s nominee as the next U.S. ambassador to Israel, on Wednesday at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
